definitions: produce a sudden bright light that appears and disappears quickly
move or pass by with great speed in an instant
show or display something briefly or suddenly to someone
examples: Lightning flashed across the dark sky during the storm
The camera flash hurt my eyes in the darkness
The sports car flashed past us on the highway
She flashed a quick smile before leaving the room
He flashed his badge to the security guard quickly
The screen flashed an error message for two seconds

definitions: place a picture or document in a rigid structure for display or protection
create or formulate something such as a plan, statement, or set of ideas
make someone appear guilty of a crime they did not commit through false evidence
examples: She decided to frame her diploma and hang it proudly
We need to frame this painting before the exhibition
The lawyer carefully framed her argument for the jury
How you frame the question determines the type of answer
The corrupt officer tried to frame him for theft
They claimed someone was trying to frame them for murder

definitions: manage and be responsible for the running of a business, organization, or system
give or apply something such as medicine, a test, or punishment to someone
examples: She will administer the company while the CEO is away
The board administers the charitable foundation and its programs
The nurse will administer the vaccine at noon today
Teachers must administer the standardized test fairly to all students

definitions: prevent someone from giving full attention to something by drawing their focus elsewhere
examples: Please don't distract me while I'm trying to concentrate
The loud music distracted the students from their homework

definitions: regard someone or something as important and worthwhile in your life
estimate the monetary worth or importance of something in specific terms
examples: I really value our friendship after all these years
She values honesty above all other qualities in people
The jeweler will value your ring for insurance purposes
They need to value the property before selling the house

definitions: admit or state that you have committed a crime or done something wrong
admit or acknowledge something reluctantly, typically personal feelings or beliefs
examples: The suspect finally confessed to stealing the money yesterday
She confessed her mistake to her boss this morning
He confessed his love for her under the stars
I must confess that I don't understand the instructions

definitions: form a mental image or representation of something in your mind
examples: Can you picture yourself living in a small town
I can't picture him as a father quite yet

definitions: move gently back and forth or from side to side rhythmically
cause great shock or disturbance to someone or something suddenly
perform excellently or be very good at doing something
examples: She gently rocked the baby to sleep in her arms
The boat rocked slowly on the calm ocean waves
The scandal rocked the entire political establishment last year
The earthquake rocked buildings throughout the downtown area yesterday
You really rock at playing guitar in the band
This new restaurant rocks with its amazing fusion cuisine

definitions: formally forbid something by law, rule, or other authority with consequences
examples: The law prohibits smoking in all public buildings here
School rules prohibit students from using phones during class

definitions: calculate the mean value by adding quantities and dividing by how many
achieve or amount to as a typical or mean level over time
examples: Let me average these test scores to find the result
The teacher will average all homework grades for final score
We average about fifty customers per day at our store
The team averages three goals per game this season consistently

definitions: make or become sound or healthy again after injury, illness, or damage
examples: The wound should heal completely in about two weeks
Time will heal the pain of losing a loved one

definitions: shout for joy or in praise and encouragement of someone or something
make someone feel happier or more positive about a situation
examples: The crowd cheered loudly when their team scored a goal
Parents cheer for their children at the school play
This good news will cheer her up after yesterday
A funny movie always cheers me when I feel down

definitions: turn or bend something into a different shape by rotating parts in opposite directions
change or distort the meaning or interpretation of words, facts, or situations deliberately
examples: Twist the cap clockwise to open the bottle properly
She twisted her ankle while running on uneven ground
Don't twist my words to suit your own agenda
The media sometimes twists facts to create sensational stories

definitions: build something again after it has been damaged, destroyed, or changed significantly
examples: They plan to rebuild the bridge after the flood damage
It takes time to rebuild trust after a betrayal

definitions: grow old or older showing signs of time passing on appearance
undergo a process of maturing or developing characteristics over an extended time period
examples: We all age differently depending on genetics and lifestyle
The stress of the job aged him ten years
This wine will age beautifully in the cellar for years
The cheese needs to age for six months before serving

definitions: communicate or make known a message, information, or feeling to someone effectively
transport or carry someone or something to a particular place or destination
examples: Her smile conveyed more than words ever could express
Please convey my regards to your family this evening
The pipeline conveys oil across hundreds of miles safely
This ancient road conveyed goods between major trading cities

definitions: argue about a subject in a formal manner presenting different viewpoints systematically
examples: The senators will debate the new healthcare bill tomorrow
Students love to debate controversial topics in philosophy class

definitions: bend something over on itself so one part covers another part
cease operations or give up in a competition or endeavor
gently mix ingredients by lifting and turning them without stirring vigorously
examples: Please fold the letter before putting it in the envelope
She taught him how to fold paper into origami shapes
The company had to fold after losing major investors
He decided to fold his poker hand rather than bet
Carefully fold the egg whites into the chocolate mixture
Fold the flour into the batter using gentle motions

definitions: wait for an event, person, or opportunity with expectation of its arrival
examples: We eagerly await your decision on the job offer
The jury's verdict awaits after three days of deliberation

definitions: give a polite word or sign of welcome or recognition when meeting someone
examples: She always greets customers with a warm smile daily
The host will greet guests at the entrance tonight

definitions: come together or bring people or things together in one place for a purpose
fit together the separate component parts of a machine, structure, or object
examples: The students will assemble in the auditorium for announcements
The team assembles every Monday to discuss project progress
It took hours to assemble the new furniture from Sweden
Workers assemble cars on the factory production line daily

definitions: make partial or minor changes to something to improve it or make it suitable
examples: We need to modify the design based on customer feedback
She modified her diet to include more vegetables daily

definitions: transmit information or instructions by means of a gesture, sound, or action
be an indication or evidence of the existence or occurrence of something
examples: The referee will signal when the game should start
She signaled to the waiter that we needed the check
Dark clouds signal that a storm is approaching quickly
This decision signals a major shift in company policy

definitions: provide funds for a project, activity, person, or organization in return for advertising
examples: The company will sponsor the local marathon this year
Many businesses sponsor youth sports teams in the community

definitions: move forward on hands and knees or by dragging the body close to ground
move or progress very slowly in an annoying or frustrating manner
examples: The baby is learning to crawl around the living room
Soldiers had to crawl under the barbed wire fence
Traffic crawled along the highway during rush hour today
Time seemed to crawl during the boring three-hour lecture

definitions: express complete disapproval of something or someone, typically in public and harsh terms
sentence someone to a particular punishment, especially death, in a court of law
officially declare something unfit for use or dangerous to occupy
examples: World leaders condemn the use of chemical weapons in warfare
The community condemned the mayor's racist remarks yesterday strongly
The judge condemned the criminal to life in prison today
In ancient times, prisoners were condemned to hard labor
The city condemned the old building as structurally unsafe
Health inspectors condemned the restaurant after finding violations

definitions: write or name the letters that form a word in correct sequence
have something as a consequence or result indicating future outcomes
take turns with another person doing a particular job or duty
examples: Can you spell your last name for the record please
Young children learn to spell simple words in kindergarten
This budget cut could spell disaster for our department
Dark economic indicators spell trouble for small businesses nationwide
I'll spell you at the night watch in two hours
Nurses spell each other during long shifts at the hospital

definitions: arrange for a room, seat, or ticket to be kept for particular person's use
refrain from using or keep back for future use or special purpose
refrain from expressing or showing emotions, opinions, or judgments openly
examples: Please reserve a table for four at the restaurant
I need to reserve a rental car for next weekend
We should reserve some funds for emergency expenses later
The coach reserves his best players for crucial moments
She tends to reserve judgment until hearing all sides
He reserves his emotions even in difficult situations

definitions: get or bring something back from somewhere it was left or stored
find and bring back information especially from a computer storage system
examples: I need to retrieve my jacket from the restaurant
The dog loves to retrieve sticks thrown into water
Can you retrieve that file from the backup drive
The system can retrieve data from five years ago

definitions: move quickly up or back from a surface after hitting it
move up and down repeatedly with energy and enthusiasm
force someone to leave a place or position unceremoniously
examples: The basketball will bounce higher on concrete than grass
The ball bounced off the wall into his hands
The excited children bounce around the playground all day
She bounced into the room with infectious enthusiasm
The security guard will bounce troublemakers from the club
They bounced him from the team after breaking rules

definitions: strike with the fist using force typically aimed at a person or object
make a hole in something using a sharp tool or special device
examples: He wanted to punch the wall in frustration yesterday
The boxer can punch with incredible force and accuracy
Please punch holes in these papers for the binder
Workers punch their time cards when arriving at work

definitions: break open or apart suddenly and violently especially from internal pressure
suddenly begin to do something or experience a strong emotion
examples: The water pipe burst during the freezing winter night
Be careful not to burst the balloon with that pin
She burst into tears when hearing the sad news
The children burst through the door after school ended

definitions: give an authoritative order that must be obeyed by others
be in charge of a military unit, organization, or area
deserve and be able to get attention, respect, or high price
examples: The general will command troops to advance at dawn
She commanded everyone to leave the room immediately
He commands the naval fleet in the Pacific Ocean
She commands a team of fifty software engineers
Her paintings command high prices at international auctions
His presence commands respect wherever he goes

definitions: go somewhere secretly and quietly trying to avoid being seen or heard
examples: He tried to sneak into the house after midnight
The cat likes to sneak up on unsuspecting birds

definitions: look at quickly but not very thoroughly to find particular information
examine systematically using a beam of light, electrons, or other detecting device
convert a document or picture into digital form for computer storage
examples: She scanned the menu looking for vegetarian options quickly
I scan the newspaper headlines every morning before work
The doctor will scan your brain for any abnormalities
Security guards scan all bags entering the building
Please scan these documents and email them to me
The librarian scans old photographs to preserve them digitally

definitions: fasten or close something securely to prevent access, leakage, or tampering
put an official mark on a document to show it is genuine or confirmed
examples: Please seal the envelope before mailing the letter
We need to seal the windows before winter arrives
The notary will seal the document with her official stamp
Both countries will seal the agreement with their signatures

definitions: publicly acknowledge someone as a participant in the production or creation of something
believe that someone or something has a particular quality or has achieved something
examples: The article should credit all contributing authors properly
They credit her with inventing the new filing system
I credit him with more sense than that
You have to credit her story after seeing the evidence

definitions: feel sad, disappointed, or sorry about something that has happened or been done
examples: I deeply regret missing your wedding last summer
She will regret this decision for years to come

definitions: identify clearly and definitely stating exact requirements, needs, or instructions in detail
examples: Please specify which color you prefer for the walls
The contract must specify all terms and conditions clearly

definitions: trip or momentarily lose balance while walking or running
make a mistake or repeated mistakes in speaking or performing an action
discover something by chance or accident rather than deliberate searching
examples: She stumbled on the uneven sidewalk but caught herself
Don't stumble in the dark without a flashlight
The nervous student stumbled over his words during presentation
Even experienced actors sometimes stumble during live performances
Researchers stumbled upon an ancient tomb while digging
I stumbled across this great restaurant while exploring downtown

definitions: remove all coverings, clothing, or outer layers from something or someone
deprive someone of rank, power, possessions, or property as punishment
examples: We need to strip the old paint before repainting
The mechanic will strip the engine to find problems
The court can strip him of his medical license
They stripped her of the championship title after cheating

definitions: control or influence a person or situation cleverly, unfairly, or unscrupulously
handle, control, or use something with skill especially with hands
examples: Some politicians manipulate voters through fear and false promises
Don't let him manipulate you into doing his work
The surgeon can manipulate tiny instruments with incredible precision
Artists manipulate clay to create beautiful sculptures

definitions: give up something important or valued for the sake of other considerations
examples: Parents often sacrifice their dreams for their children
She sacrificed her career to care for her family

definitions: squeeze someone tightly in your arms to express affection, greeting, or comfort
examples: She ran to hug her mother after returning home
Friends hug each other goodbye at the airport

definitions: cause a person, place, or thing to be alone or apart from others
examples: The doctor will isolate patients with contagious diseases immediately
Don't isolate yourself from friends during difficult times

definitions: officially register as a member, student, or participant in something
examples: Students must enroll in classes before the semester begins
She decided to enroll in an online cooking course

definitions: come or bring together for a common purpose, forming a single entity
examples: The two companies will unite to form a larger corporation
Crisis often unites people who were previously divided

definitions: tell a humorous anecdote or make witty remarks to provoke laughter
speak or act without being serious about what you say
examples: He loves to joke around during lunch breaks
Comedians joke about everyday situations to make people laugh
Don't joke about such serious matters please
I was only joking when I said that

definitions: look keenly or with difficulty at someone or something
examples: She had to peer through the fog to see
The doctor will peer into your throat during examination

definitions: trick or deceive someone into believing something that is not true
behave in a silly, playful, or teasing way without serious intent
examples: Don't let appearances fool you into making assumptions
The magician fooled everyone with his clever illusions
Stop fooling around and finish your homework please
The kids love to fool with their new toys
